title: Are You Prepared for Managing Your Diabetes in an Emergency?

content: Last summer, as I sat down to dinner with my sister and brother-in-law in their home in Norman, OK, the sky suddenly turned black. Severe thunderstorms kicked up, followed by TV reports of tornadoes circling the area. Abandoning our food, we crowded into their steel-reinforced pantry/tornado shelter, listening as the TV broadcast a street-by-street report of the twisters’ paths.
This was serious business: Only a few months earlier, a monster tornado had cost several residents their lives.

As a first-timer, it was both frightening and a bit exhilarating to be caught in a situation I had never experienced before. Thunder cracked above as the wind picked up speed. Although we were supposed to stay put until the “all clear,” once or twice, my sister or brother-in-law poked their heads out of the shelter door to track the twisters on TV, where storm chasers recorded those that had made landfall, signaled by sharp bursts of sparks as they hit live electric wires. Only when daylight arrived would it be possible to assess the damage.

content: As the song goes, “Summertime and the living is easy.” But hotter temps can also bring wild weather – sudden thunderstorms that wreak havoc on electrical grids, hurricanes, and tornadoes that can send you to emergency shelters. Or worse.

No twisters touched down in Norman that night. But what if one had? I carried enough pills for my stay, and my refrigerated medication would go bad in a few days. While the East Coast where I live experiences tornados, we did register a mild earthquake this past spring. A bit alarmed at my own lack of preparedness, I decided to make a diabetes care plan based on tips from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Among their ideas:

Make a diabetes care kit: Gathering medical information in a waterproof bag or container can be invaluable. The CDC suggests including copies of prescriptions, a list of dosages and times when you take medications, along with your pharmacy and doctor’s name, address, and phone number. You might want to list the make, model, and serial number of your insulin pump, if you use one, or continuous glucose monitor along with a copy of your photo ID and health insurance cards. (I also saved all this information in a phone app.)

sections.heading: One to two weeks of supplies:
content: If possible, try to stockpile enough of your oral diabetes and other prescription medicines, along with any injectables you take. If the medication requires refrigeration, know how long it might last without it. Small cases with freezer packs are available online and can keep medications cold for several days, some longer. Extra batteries for blood sugar meters and insulin pumps can also be helpful, along with lancets, glucose measuring strips, lancing devices, and alcohol wipes.

To treat low sugars, don’t forget glucose tablets or 15 grams of quick carbs such as orange juice, hard candy, or honey. Other supplies could include water and high-protein snacks like small packages of nuts, sealed packets of peanut butter, or canned tuna.

Keep up to date: Once you have your supplies, be sure to check storage instructions and expiration dates every few months, so you can replace items when they are close to expiring. (You can use the kit supplies for your daily care before they reach the expiration date.)

sections.heading: Consider a medical necklace or bracelet:
content: Emergency workers are taught to check for medical IDs in cases where you may be unable to communicate yourself. It’s not a great thought, but as in all emergencies, it’s good to be prepared.
